sen.j: 民間では、こうした農耕神を一般に田の神と呼称してきたが、東北地方では「農神」（のうがみ）、甲信地方（山梨県・長野県）では「作神」（さくがみ）、近畿地方では「作り神」、但馬国（兵庫県）や因幡国（鳥取県）では「亥（い）の神」、中国地方・四国地方では「サンバイ（様）」また瀬戸内海沿岸では「地神」などとも呼ばれる。
sen.e: In a folk belief, such agricultural god has been generally called Tanokami but regionally "No-gami" in Tohoku region, "Saku-gami" in Koshin Region (Yamanashi and Nagano Prefectures), "Tsukuri-gami" in Kinki Region, "I-no-kami" in Tajima Province (Hyogo Prefecture) and Inaba Province (Tottori Prefecture), "Sanbai-(sama)" in Chugoku and Shikoku Regions, and "Chijin (earthly deities)" in regions along the coast of Seto Inland Sea.

sen.j: 山の神信仰は、古くより、狩猟や焼畑耕作、炭焼、杣（木材の伐採）や木挽（製材）、木地師（木器製作）、鉱山関係者など、おもに山で暮らす人々によって、それぞれの生業に応じた独特の信仰や宗教的な行為が形成され伝承されてきた。
sen.e: Worship of Yamanokami has been formed and handed down by people living mainly in mountains such as those engaged in hunting, swidden agriculture, charcoal burners, woodcutters, sawyers, kijishi (wood master) (wood vessel production) and miners in their unique faith and religious behaviors according to the occupations.

The worship of Yamanokami has been formed and handed down by people living mainly in mountains such as those engaged in hunting, swidden agriculture, charcoal burners, woodcutters, sawyers, kijishi (wood master) (wood vessel production) and miners having their unique faith and religious behaviors according to their occupations.

sen.j: いっぽう、稲作農耕民の間には山の神が春の稲作開始時期になると家や里へ下って田の神となり、田仕事にたずさわる農民の作業を見守り、稲作の順調な推移を助けて豊作をもたらすとする信仰があった。
sen.e: In addition, there was a belief among rice farmers that Yamanokami descended from the mountain to villages or houses to become Tanokami and watch over farmers working in the fields in spring when rice cultivation starts, and helped healthy growth of rice and brought about a good harvest.

Rice farmers believed that the Yamanokami descended from the mountain to villages or houses to become Tanokami and watch over farmers working in the fields in spring when rice cultivation starts, and helped rice to grow, bringing about a good harvest.

sen.j: これを、田の神・山の神の春秋去来の伝承といい、全国各地に広くみられる。

sen.e: In this way, the three gods--Yashiki-gami (family house god), the agricultural god, and Sorei-shin--had close relations with each other centering on the a god of crop soul (Toshigami (god of the incoming year)).

sen.j: 予祝芸能行事としては、東京都板橋区にのこる板橋の田遊びや和歌山県かつらぎ町花園の花園の御田舞（ともに重要無形民俗文化財）が、年頭や小正月におこなわれるものとしては古い形態をよくとどめている。
sen.e: Among events of Yoshuku Geino (Preliminary Celebration), Taasobi (ritual Shinto performance to pray for a good rice-crop for the year) handed down in Itabashi Ward, Tokyo and Hanazono no Ondamai (the rice field dance in Hanazono) performed in Hanazono, Katsuragi-cho, Wakayama Prefecture (both being designated as Important Intangible Property of Folk Culture) well retain the old forms as a event held at New Year or Lunar New Year.

sen.e: Akiu no Taue-odori (the rice planting dance in Akiu) (designated as Important Intangible Property of Folk Culture) held in Akiu, Sendai City, Miyagi Prefecture in every April today was originally a Yoshuku Geino (Preliminary Celebration) held on Lunar New Year in the depth of winter.

sen.e: Other folk events having a characteristic of the preliminary celebration include events of Niwataue such as "Secchutaue" in Yoshida, Yokote City, Akita Prefecture and "Enburi (a rice planting dance named after a tool for rice field preparation)" in Hachinohe City, Aomori Prefecture.

Other folk events having a characteristic of the preliminary celebration include events of Niwataue (literally, rice planting in the garden) such as 'Secchutaue (literally, race planting in snow)' in Yoshida, Yokote City, Akita Prefecture and 'Enburi (a rice planting dance named after a tool for rice field preparation)' in Hachinohe City, Aomori Prefecture.

sen.j: さらに、田の神そのものではないが、それと深くかかわるものとしては、東日本に広く伝承されている小正月の鳥追い行事、かまくらなど水神の祭礼、どんど焼きをはじめとする左義長の行事、また、ナマハゲ・サイノカミ・トシドン・アマハゲなど日本各地に広がるトシノカミの訪問も予祝の性格をもつ民俗行事である。
sen.e: In addition, the following events are also folk events having a characteristic of the preliminary celebration, although they do not directly involve Tanokami itself but have close relations with it: bird-driving events widely handed down in East Japan, festivals of God of Water and Rain such as a mid-January festival in northern Japan, with snow huts in which children play house, a festival of Sagicho (ritual bonfire of New Year's decorations) such as the Dondon-yaki (a Shinto blessing of objects that have been a part of a celebration but are now debris comsuming by fire at the 14th to the 16the of the lunar New Year), visits of Toshinokami widely seen in regions across Japan such as namahage (folklore demons of the Oga Peninsula that pay frightening visits to children at the New Year), Sae-no-kami, Tshidon and Amahage.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: In addition, the following events are also folk events having a characteristic of the preliminary celebration, although they do not directly involve Tanokami itself but have close relations with it: bird-driving events widely handed down in East Japan, festivals of God of Water and Rain such as a mid-January festival in northern Japan, with snow huts in which children play house, a festival of Sagicho (ritual bonfire of New Year's decorations) such as the Dondon-yaki (a Shinto blessing of objects that have been a part of a celebration but are now debris comsuming by fire at the 14th to the 16the of the lunar New Year), visits of Toshinokami widely seen in regions across Japan such as namahage (folklore demons of the Oga Peninsula that pay frightening visits to children at the New Year), Sae-no-kami, Tshidon and Amahage.

In addition, the following events are also folk events having a characteristic of the preliminary celebration, although they do not directly involve Tanokami itself but have close relations with it: bird-driving events widely handed down in East Japan, festivals of God of Water and Rain such as a mid-January festival in northern Japan, snow huts in which children play house, a festival of Sagicho (ritual bonfire of New Year's decorations) including the Dondo-yaki (a bonfire of the New Year's decorations, such as pine branches, bamboos, and straw festoons, at a shrine around the 15th of January), visits of Toshinokami widely seen in regions across Japan such as namahage (folklore demons of the Oga Peninsula that pay frightening visits to children at the New Year), Sai-no-kami, Toshidon and Amahage.

sen.e: One example is a festival in Marumori-machi, Miyagi Prefecture, in which Gohei (wooden wands, decorated with two Shide (zigzag paper streamers)) containing branches of Yaezakura (double cherry blossoms) and roasted rice is erected at Mizuguchi of rice nursery fields.

sen.j: 大田植は、字義通りには大規模な田植ということだが、最も多く植える日、田植盛りの日、最も大きな田の田植日、田植終いの日など、さまざまな意味で用いられる。
sen.e: Ootauue literally means a large scale rice planting but is used in a variety of meanings such as the day when the largest quantity is planted, the day when rice planting is at the peak, the day when rice is planted in the largest field, and the last day of rice planting.

sen.j: 中国地方の山間I部では、旧家の由緒ある田に美しく着飾ったウシを入れて代かきをし、ささら・笛・太鼓・鉦などの囃に合わせて田植歌をうたいながら早乙女たちが田植をすることを大田植と呼んでいる。
sen.e: In some mountainous areas in Chugoku region, Otaue refers to a rice planting by young female rice planters singing according to sasara (a Japanese traditional percussion instrument), fue (Japanese flute), drum, a bell and other hayashi (musical accompaniment played on traditional Japanese instruments) in an old family's rice field with a history after soil puddling by beautifully dressed up cows.

sen.j: 形態的には、以下の系統の異なる2流の展開がみとめられる。
sen.e: There are the following two different lines of changes that the shape of the stones underwent:

sen.e: The shape of the stones undergo the following two different lines of change:
The shape of the stones undergo the following two different lines of change:

sen.j: 仏像型 → 僧型 → 旅僧型
sen.e: Buddhist image type => Buddhist monk type => Travelling monk type
Buddhist image type => Buddhist monk type => Travelling monk type
Buddhist image type => Buddhist monk type => Travelling monk type

sen.j: 神像型 → 神職型 → 田の神舞型（または神舞神職型）
sen.e: Sacred image type => Shinto priest type =>Dancing Tanokami type (or Sacred dancing priest type)
Sacred image type => Shinto priest type =>Dancing Tanokami type (or Sacred dancing priest type)
Sacred image type => Shinto priest type =>Dancing Tanokami type (or Sacred dancing priest type)

sen.j: これについては、小野重朗による詳細な研究がある。
sen.e: Juro ONO studied this in details.
Juro ONO studied this in detail.
Juro ONO studied this in detail.

sen.j: ただし、田の神講そのものは他地域でも広くみられる。
sen.e: However, Tanokami-ko itself is found in other regions.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: However, Tanokami-ko itself is found in other regions.

sen.j: 「田神」「田ノ神」「田の神」の文字の彫られた石碑は南九州に限らず、全国の路傍などに広汎に分布している。
sen.e: Stones statues with carved characters of "田神," "田ノ神," and "田の神" are widely found by the roadside not only in souther Kyushu but also across Japan.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: Stones statues with carved characters of "田神," "田ノ神," and "田の神" are widely found by the roadside not only in southern Kyushu but also across Japan.

sen.j: 全国に狐塚の地名は多い。
sen.e: The place-name of Kitsune-zuka is commonly found across Japan.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: The place-name of Kitsune-zuka is commonly found across Japan.

sen.j: これはかつてキツネが田の神の神使だと考えられていたことに由来する。
sen.e: This is because the fox was once regarded as Shinshi (a divine servant) of Tanokami.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: This is because the fox was once regarded as Shinshi (a divine servant) of Tanokami.

sen.j: 田の近くに塚（狐塚）をきずいてまつったわけで、のちに、こうした祭場に稲荷神の祠を勧請した。
sen.e: Mounds (fox mounds) were built near rice fields and later became hokora (a small shrine) of Inari-shin (the god of harvest) to appeal to the gods

sen.j: このことが稲荷信仰が全国的に広がる契機となったものと考えられている。
sen.e: This is considered to have caused Inari faith to spread nationwide.
